content: [Applause]
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts so I made some snow hills got myself some trees and I even made a
custom snow golem miniature now I needed something to put it all on to actually
run a snow encounter the thing about snow is it can be represented with a
sheet of anything that is white there is a lot of different options my first
inclination was to use some white felt so I went to the fabric store to pick
some up then I kind of remembered how the felt on my gaming table was like a
friggin magnet for crumbs and dirt felt is like velcro and it just grabs every
little piece of ya with white felt I figured that was a bad
idea and it would quickly get grimy and gross so I kiboshed that as I looked
around I came across some white vinyl and I thought that might be perfect I
grabbed a big sheet of this white vinyl I figured I could probably use it as a
battle mat that I could draw on with a dry erase or wet erase marker turns out
that didn't really work the surface wasn't glossy enough and it was kind of
porous so erasing would just make a sand muddy mess the plan was to cut it down
to the size of my gaming table then I used it as a backdrop in my Snow Hill
photography I realized it was just a really great thing as a backdrop and
since it wasn't the cheapest it was like a $25 sheet of material I didn't want to
cut it up I just want to keep it for photography so I'm you're going to Plan
C and I remembered my fat zebra gaming mat the size of one of those mats is
just plain white with a black grid I don't usually use it very much because I
think it's kind of boring just being plain white but for snow it'd be perfect
if I wasn't a content creator that's what I would do that wouldn't make much
of a video if I just ended it right here instead use a white battle mat so I knew
what I had to do I had to build something custom I had to build my own
snow battle boards so that's what I did let's take a look
built them I started by measuring the open area of my gaming table it's 32
inches square so to make the board's easy to place I wanted them to create a
30 by 30 playing area this meant I'd need 4 15 inch square pieces of foam it
would be great to do this in one single piece but I really didn't want to have
to store a board that big and I also didn't want to have to buy a sheet of
foam big enough to do that when cutting squares I never rely on a t-square
as they are often inaccurate I'll square off one side with a large carpenter's
square then do the last cuts by measuring out my desired width on the
top and bottom if done right this is the most accurate way to cut large squares
that are true when cutting with a blade it's very important to try to keep the
knife plumb to the material and do several light passes to get clean square
cuts with material that was now of a more manageable size I went back to my
cutting mat to finish the other cuts again the best way to make sure these
state's square was to measure the desired width at the top and bottom of
the piece from a side that I knew to be true and then cut that using a straight
edge and blade I tested my pieces at the gaming table
to make sure they fit together and lined up nicely
I wanted these to have a bit of texture to them but I didn't want any sandy
aggregate or to use any snow flocking I wanted them to remain flat and playable
snow viewed from a distance isn't grainy or bumpy so I utilized my favorite
texturing technique which is just the crumpled up aluminum foil to dent the
surface of the foam this creates a surprisingly perfect
pattern for representing a snow packed bit of ground
this is where I realized a huge problem
half inch foam in squares of this big is not thick enough to stay flat the pieces
had an arch to them and had a lot of flex I kind of had a feeling this would
happen going into this project but for some reason I chose to ignore my gut
until I couldn't ignore it anymore seriously I could not use these like
this I debated using thicker foam but in the end decided I should do the correct
thing and mount these to some MDF I picked up some sheets of quarter inch
MDF which I hoped would be thick enough to stay nice and flat at this size I
didn't want to use thicker material as it would end up making the pieces way
too heavy I begrudgingly set up the table saw outside and ripped my four
squares at this point I decided to make them one inch smaller in each direction
than my original plan this way I could attach them to the foam cut off the
excess and be left with perfect pieces
once I had my MDF bases I attach them to the foam using some 3m adhesive spray I
both love and hate this stuff it bonds faster and better than anything else
I've ever used and doesn't cause any warping but it does smell like pure
chemical death so despite the chilly weather I sprayed each piece of MDF
outside then ran indoors to wear my foam was waiting and slapped the two pieces
together I then cut off the excess foam on my procs on using the attached MDF as
a guide in order to do this nicely you have to take a lot more care and caution
than you'd expect you really have to make sure your wire is under the right
amount of tension your temperature isn't set to high and you feed the material at
the correct speed from front to back if you don't get this right or if you put
pressure on the wire from the side you can end up with a wavy cut or even worse
a slightly beveled cut on the foam I made sure to screw this up on a practice
piece before doing my real cuts
at this point I made a big decision I decided to put a 1-inch grid on my
boards now in the past I've gone on at length about how you don't need a grid
for D&D check the video in the top right hand corner to see my rant personally I
freely switch between gritted and grid list play I found that a lot of the time
my players really liked the grid and it does speed up gameplay when I plan to do
these boards using only phone my thought was to make them double-sided with a
grid on one side and grid lists on the other with the MDF base I had to pick
one and I well I went with the grid I wanted it to be pretty subtle however so
I only lightly created the lines using a very sharp pencil I didn't want them to
be very deep or very wide again to get grids like this perfect it's best to
always layout from the same side and measure points at the top and bottom
then connect them with a straight edge with the grid lines complete I textured
the foam again with the same method I had done on my first piece earlier now
it was time for paint I again went with a generic household drywall primer for
this but I did mix in some PVA glue for good measure I chose not to use Mod
Podge on these because they really didn't require any of the added benefits
that Mod Podge gives over PVA they didn't have any fine detail so I wasn't
worried about things being obscured I applied the primer with a cheap dollar
store roller to speed up the process while a roller was the best way to go I
did make a mistake by using a long nap low quality roller this meant that it
shed a lot of little fibers into the paint that I didn't notice until it was
dry and too late I'd recommend using a short nap roller especially if using a
cheap one from the dollar store as the short nap fibers are less likely to shed
and make your piece look awful I decided to bring out the lines and
texture using a very subtle blue wash I wanted to ensure the wash really settled
into the low spots and didn't stain the white so I made it by mixing water and
pledge floor polish in a 50/50 ratio then adding just a very very tiny amount
of Vallejo blue wash I also added in one tiny drop of the
pearlescent paint I had tried on my snow hills previously I had faith that using
this pearlescent paint in a much more subtle way would be effective and
actually ended up putting a coat on my snow hills from last week as well
I applied the wash using a simple spray bottle from the dollar store the effect
was just enough to bring out the details without looking too silly and the little
bit of gloss from the pledge actually helped the effect in my opinion while
just using a white battle matte surely would have been a perfectly fine
solution I'm glad I went through the effort to make these and I'm pretty
happy with how they turned out if you want to pick up any tools or supplies
for your builds head over to black magic crafts CA where I have my essential
equipment store with links to all of the things I use and recommend those links
are Amazon affiliate links so shopping with them is a great way to help fund
these videos also be sure to check out the video description below for links to
products specific to this build if you love these videos that I make and you
want to help me keep making them the best way you can do that is by
supporting black magic crafts on patreon the support on patreon is crucial to
allow me to put all of my time and effort into these videos and this
community I'd love to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts
fellowship there you have it guys custom snow battle boards complete I hope you
found that build entertaining informative and most of all inspiring
especially all the parts where I had trouble because it's important to
remember that builds don't always go smoothly actually they rarely go
smoothly and it's in those difficult problematic points where you have to
pivot into a different idea where the best things are learned you just
remember that next time you encounter a problem with your build if you enjoyed
this video hit that like but and let me know in the comments section
below what I'd really like to hear however is what you use at home for your
snow battle board because I'm sure there's some options or ideas they
didn't think of so let me know in the comments section I would love to hear
what I missed that's it for this week guys Cheers I will see you again next
week
